>
> > +                                    bias=self._h2h_gates_bias,
> +                                    num_hidden=self._num_hidden * 2,
> +                                    name="%s_h2h_gates" % name)
> +        i2h, i2h_z, i2h_r = symbol.SliceChannel(i2h, num_outputs=3,
> +                                                name="%s_i2h_slice" % name)
> +        h2h_z, h2h_r = symbol.SliceChannel(h2h, num_outputs=2,
> +                                           name="%s_h2h_gates_slice" % name)
> +
> +        update_gate = symbol.Activation(i2h_z + h2h_z, act_type="sigmoid", name="%s_z_act" % name)
> +        reset_gate = symbol.Activation(i2h_r + h2h_r, act_type="sigmoid", name="%s_r_act" % name)
> +
> +        next_h_tmp = symbol.FullyConnected(data=(reset_gate * prev_state_h),
> +                                           weight=self._h2h_weight,
> +                                           bias=self._h2h_bias,
> +                                           num_hidden=self._num_hidden,
> +                                           name="%s_h2h" % name)
>
> In cudnn v5.0, the GRU is like tanh(W_h x_t + r_t \circ (R_h h_{t-1} +
> b_{R_h}) + b_{W_h}). Should we make GRU the same as cudnn?

Created a pull request #5221. Thank you @horserma.

I haven't added reflection padding. Replicate is working working on the dims supported. If you would like to help, there are two projects:
* Currently, only padding for the spatial dimensions of 2d + 3d images is supported (when images are represented as [c,h,w] format). It is good having a fast code path for these, but it would be nice to support padding for arbitrary tensor shapes (like tensorflow supports)
* add reflection padding support

things i would check:
- if you run your prediction (same one as on the test set) on the validation set, do you find 86%? there could be an index problem somewhere
- is your split between train/val/test really random? (dataset can be biased)

1) Yes
2) I am using caret's createDataPartition function to do my splitting. If I am not mistaken, that should do randomized splitting.

I tried plot all three errors depending on iteration (I saved model every 5 iterations) and behavior of testing error got even weirder (at least for me) - testing starts on ~50% accuracy and every iteration goes lower and lower. Training and validation does the opposite but in larger steps - validation accuracy ends on 86 % (change 46% from start) and testing stops 6% below starting value.
maybe check the % of outcome per dataset? is it the same in test as val and train?

Hi,

I think you should have same size of input and output datasets when using `mx.lstm`.

```
library(mxnet)
data(iris)
y <- as.integer(iris$Species)[1:5!=5]
x <- iris[1:5!=5,-5]

input <- t(x)
output <- rbind(t(y), matrix(0,ncol=length(y), nrow=3))

test <- iris[1:5==5,]

model <- mx.lstm(
     list(data = input, label = output),
     list(data = input, label = output),
     ctx = mx.gpu(),
     update.period = 1,
     num.lstm.layer = 1, 
     num.hidden = 4, 			
     num.embed = 1, 
     
     seq.len = 4,
     num.label = 3,
     input.size = 1,
     
     num.round = 5, 
     batch.size = 4, 
     initializer = mx.init.uniform(0.1), 
     learning.rate = 0.05,
     clip_gradient = 1
)
```

`seq.len` should match row size and `batch.size` should match with columns size.

Another thing is this dataset.
I don't know what's the purpose of using lstm model for this kind of data (iris), but it's not the point here.

I hope this helps, I've also been struggling these issues with `mx.lstm` .

@sbodenstein: so replicate is working, that is wonderful wonderful :) I'd like to help with adding reflection padding support first. Please let me know where your replicate code is, and I can work on implementing reflection in a consistent way, test/compare with tensorflow. Are you working from https://github.com/sbodenstein/mxnet/tree/master/src/operator?

Thanks for the help! That helped me narrow things down. Last night I got it working on both operating systems. 

In case anyone has a similar problem in the future:
I had installed MXNet prior to RMSProp moving to NNVM. I used `git pull && update && make clean && make -j$(nproc)` to recompile the C++ interface after the new updates were introduced, and then updated the python interface. This is around the time that the NaNs started appearing, so I'm guessing there was a mismatch between the Python & C++ interface. Since it wasn't reproducible I decided to completely uninstall & reinstall everything from scratch (on both the Python and C++ side). I ran my scripts with RMSProp last night and they seem to be working fine.
@szha @piiswrong I added the MKL job (disabled it after it finished) and Python tests passed.

I think one solution is to put the compiled dll to the listed candidate directories. Also, you may try install the package via `python setup.py develop --user`.

Hi @tornadomeet, I tested it on a Linux server with 4 K40 GPU, it can achieve linear speedup, and I used the CXX Proposal operator.
i implement `train_end2end.py` and test in a linux server with 6 k80 at that time, it will not get linear spped up. so have you rewritten the proposal operator with c++?
I take C++ operator from https://github.com/precedenceguo/mx-rcnn/tree/master/operator. I think the python operator should not be the critical point.

It seems to be an IO problem, when I skip the get_batch function and use use a pre-computed mini-batch it could get linear speedup. But it supposed to be async and won't have such huge impact, right? And it works well on Linux, so I wonder what's wrong with it, does windows has any limitation?

It seems the current cudnn batchnorm implementation requires the input dimension <= 4. Updates are needed to either call cuDNN's general ND tensor API or use `get_with_shape` to fake 4D tensors out of ND.

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/cudnn_batch_norm-inl.h#L62

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/5151/files#diff-4ae864e473b6f349d054aad47522e2e0R78
you need to do this change for scala too.

Hi all,

I've been trying to tackle this problem for some time. From my investigation, cocl does not work very well because mshadow is built on Thrust which uses a lot of CUDA host side API that are not supported by cocl. @delijati 
Therefore, what we found promising is to use [VexCL](https://github.com/ddemidov/vexcl) as the vector expression library (instead of mshadow) for GPU device. Currently I have most arithmetic operators on NDArray working but still need to fill in a hell lot of symbolic operators for the whole framework to work. Proof of concept code is here: https://github.com/windywinter/mxnet

Hi @thirdwing, here is what i did:
1. run program above without resize and with 28 28 3 shape
2. added resize 56
3. run program above with 56 56 3 shape

How about add a dtype parameter to allow uint8, int32, and float32?
I don't there there would be much difference speed wise between int16 and int32.
Also since you are going to convert it to float later anyway, why not directly convert to float in imdecode
I could have made a mistake. Do you get better result after the change?
Data is discrete. Embedding is non-differentiable wrt data
I think merging is a good idea. Not sure about submodule though. We have too many submodules already
@piiswrong: could you have a look at this?

The idea behind `uint16` is that they can be stored in tifs which I know opencv can read, I am not sure about int32 and imdecode. 
In the end, what image formats should this thing read?

We could make a new templated version of mxnet::io::Imdecode, then the orginal (and exposed) mxnet::io::Imdecode contain a have a switch, which choses the correct templated function based on the dtype param.

So you are suggesting that we drop mshadow::kUint8 and replace with mshadow::float16? I have not looked in depth at mxnet and mshadow, but I assume most processing is done on singles (float16).

yes something like mx.io.imdecode(..., dtype='float32') should work.
We don't need to make imdecode templated. We only need to do a conversion at the end with MSHADOW_DTYPE_SWITCH like the other ops.

Thanks, by the way, what should I do to avoid the error? Write embedding layer outside of caption module? 发自网易邮箱大师 在2017年03月06日 04:19，Eric Junyuan Xie 写道： Data is discrete. Embedding is non-differentiable wrt data — You are receiving this because you authored the thread. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.
the profiler gives very low level times.  It does raise a question though, what is 'CopyCPU2CPU'? It is taking up a lot of cycles.
suggest remove `data_par = mx.io.PrefetchingIter([data])` and set engine type to `NaiveEngine` to profiler your code.

@Arielnabai ,You mean you don't want to print the last layer output?If you want to print the output of internal layers,one method is use `mx.symbol.Group([softmaxout,mx.symobl.BlockGrad(loss)])`,while the loss is the layer you want to output,then you can use the `EvalMetric`to print it If you don't familiar with EvalMetric,I can  share you some naive code,hope it helps.
@tornadomeet All of a sudden, I thought it may be rude to modify the naming, which does not reduce the readability.

@saicoco Change the line `word_embed = mx.sym.Embedding(data=seq, input_dim=vocab_size, output_dim=num_embed, name='seq_embed')` to
`word_embed = mx.sym.Embedding(data=mx.sym.BlockGrad(seq), input_dim=vocab_size, output_dim=num_embed, name='seq_embed')`

@lincolnBush
Here is a simple version of my own adapter. Just a toy to fit a sine() function:

```
import mxnet as mx
import numpy as np
import logging
import sys
import os
from mxnet.io import DataIter, DataBatch


class TestIterater(DataIter):

    def __init__(self,
                 data_name="data",
                 label_name="softmax_label",
                 batch_size=50):
        super(TestIterater, self).__init__()
        self.data_name = data_name
        self.label_name = label_name

        self.num_data = 100000
        self.cursor = 0
        self.batch_size = batch_size

    @property
    def provide_data(self):
        return [(self.data_name, (1, 1, 1))]

    @property
    def provide_label(self):
        return [(self.label_name, (1,))]

    def get_batch_size(self):
        return self.batch_size

    def reset(self):
        self.cursor = 0

    def iter_next(self):
        return self.cursor < self.num_data

    def next(self):
        if self.iter_next():
            self.cursor += self.batch_size
            x = np.random.uniform(0, 2 * np.pi, (self.get_batch_size(), 1, 1, 1))
            y = np.sin(x)
            y = y.reshape(self.get_batch_size(), 1)
            return DataBatch(
                data=[mx.nd.array(v) for v in x],
                label=[mx.nd.array(v) for v in y]
            )
        else:
            raise StopIteration

if __name__ == '__main__':
    train_epoch = 10
    batch_size = 5
    train_iter = TestIterater(batch_size=50)
    test_iter = TestIterater(batch_size=50)

    net_in = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
    net_in_flat = mx.symbol.Flatten(data=net_in)

    net_label = mx.symbol.Variable('softmax_label')

    fc1 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=net_in_flat, name='fc1', num_hidden=512)
    # fc1_act = mx.symbol.Activation(data=fc1, name='fc1_act', act_type='sigmoid')
    fc2 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=fc1, name='fc2', num_hidden=256)
    # fc2_act = mx.symbol.Activation(data=fc2, name='fc2_act', act_type='sigmoid')
    fc3 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=fc2, name='fc3', num_hidden=256)
    net_out = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=fc3, name='net_out', num_hidden=1)
    loss = mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(data=net_out, label=net_label, name='loss')

    logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO)
    logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)  # get a logger to accuracies are printed
    model = mx.module.Module(
        symbol=loss,
        data_names=['data'],
        label_names=['softmax_label'],
        logger=logger
    )

    model.fit(
        train_data=train_iter,
        eval_data=test_iter,
        eval_metric='mae',
        optimizer='sgd',
        # optimizer_params=(('learning_rate', 0.005), ('momentum', 0.5)),
        num_epoch=train_epoch,
        batch_end_callback=mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size, frequent=100)
    )
```

I am seems it cpu problem . get_rcnn_batch not async and it more cpu calculation, and it is run in single thread.
You can change it into a multithreaded mode,
As to why linux linear speedup.I think it's because K40 isn't fast enough.
